Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Closing the Loop on Walking: From Hybrid Systems to Bipedal Robots to Prosthetic Devices and Back

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provides funding for contributions to the foundations of hybrid systems through the anthropomorphically motivated study of dynamic walking of bipedal robots, with a special focus on behavior unique to hybrid systems and applications to prosthesis design.

Bipedal walking is a quintessential example of complex dynamically stable behavior. Hybrid systems---systems with both continuous and discrete behavior---provide a modeling paradigm in which to capture the behavior of highly complex systems, resulting in new phenomena not found in continuous and discrete systems. Bipedal walking robots are naturally modeled as hybrid systems, and it is the confluence of these two areas---bipedal walking and hybrid systems---that affords a unique opportunity to further the understanding of each of these areas.

This project uses studies of human walking to obtain accurate and anthropomorphic hybrid models of bipedal robots, designs control laws that yield human-like walking through the use of geometric reduction, formally studies the stability and robustness of the resulting hybrid systems, and uses this cumulative understanding of bipedal walking to design prosthesis devices.

The applications of the ideas underlying this project are far reaching, providing new research directions in hybrid systems and a new understanding of the fundamental mechanisms underlying walking.
Applying this understanding to the design of prosthesis devices could have a dramatic impact on the quality of life of the millions of lower body extremity amputees. Furthermore, the anthropomorphic nature of bipedal locomotion has wide appeal to people of all ages and demographics, greatly facilitating outreach and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans have the ability to walk with deceptive ease, navigating everything from daily environments to uneven and uncertain terrain with efficiency and robustness.  If the fundamental mechanisms underlying human walking can be discovered and formally understood, human-like abilities can be infused into the next generation of robotic devices with far-reaching applications ranging from prostheses to legged robots for space exploration and disaster response.  With a view toward achieving human-like locomotion abilities on robotic systems, this project developed a framework for formally achieving bipedal robotic walking through controller synthesis inspired by human locomotion, and it demonstrated these methods through experimental realization on numerous bipedal robots. 

Through the study of human locomotion data, the underlying mechanics and discrete phases of human walking can be utilized for the construction of hybrid system models with the same discrete phases, i.e., this project formally constructed hybrid models from human data.  To study the continuous dynamics associated with this hybrid model, and motivated by the hierarchical control present in humans, we took the perspective of viewing the human as a “black box” and described outputs, or virtual constraints, that appear to characterize human walking.  By considering the equivalent outputs for a bipedal robot, a novel type of control Lyapunov function (CLF) can be constructed that drives the outputs of the robot to the outputs of the human; moreover, the parameters of this CLF can be optimized so that stable robotic walking is provably achieved for the hybrid system model while simultaneously producing outputs of the robot that are as close as possible to those of the human.  This CLF forms the basis for a Quadratic Program (QP) based control methodology that dynamically accounts for torque and contact constraints while being implementable in real-time.   The end result is the generation of bipedal robotic walking that is remarkably human-like and is experimentally realizable, together with a novel control framework for highly dynamic behaviors on bipedal robots. 

The formal framework developed through this project forms the basis for achieving a variety of advanced walking behaviors—including multi-domain locomotion, e.g., human-like heel-toe behaviors.  This is evidenced by the demonstration of the resulting controllers on multiple robotic platforms, including the AMBER series of bipedal robots custom-built to demonstrate the results of this project.  Finally, the formal framework developed through this project has led to dynamic and efficient walking on humanoid robots, e.g., DURUS.  The understanding gained from achieving human-like robotic walking naturally led to greater insight into the design and control of powered lower-limb prostheses.  This project concluded with the application of the human-inspired control framework to the custom built prosthesis: AMPRO.  In particular, gaits for the AMPRO prosthesis were generated through the same process used for bipedal robots, with the same underlying formal framework, and then applied to devices whose design was inspired by bipedal robots through the QP-based control framework.  The end result was natural and efficient prosthesis locomotion. 

This project, therefore, began with human walking as the inspiration for generating hybrid system models and control methods for bipedal robots that are formally justifiable, realized on experimental platforms, and translated to powered prostheses.   We thereby closed the loop on hybrid systems, bipedal robots and prosthesis devices.  The results of this project hopefully will lay the groundwork for further work related to formally understanding bipedal robotic locomotion in the context of hybrid system models while practically being realizable on a wide variety of robotic systems ranging from humanoid robots to robotic assistive devices.  This has the potential to pave the way for the next generation of walking robots and robotic assistive devices.
